p: Table 7 shows the association between variables of infected individuals on 17th March and 7th April 2020, and other variables: a correlation higher than 60% ( p-value < 0.001) is between air pollution and infected individuals, a lower coefficient of correlation is between density of population and infected individuals ( r = 48–53%, p-value < 0.001). Results also show a negative correlation between number of infected individuals and intensity of wind speed ( r = −38% and −31%, p-value < 0.05 on 17th March and 7th April 2020 respectively): in fact, wind speed cleans air from pollutants that are associated with possible transmission dynamics of viral infectivity (COVID-19) as it will be explained later.
